user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketBind:
```c
int32 OS_SocketBind(osal_id_t sock_id, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_SocketBindAddress(sock_id, Addr);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_SocketListen(sock_id);
        if (return_code == OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE)
        {
            /* This one is OK, it happens if the socket is a datagram/connectionless
             * type that does not need to listen().  For backward compatibility, report
             * success to the caller.
             */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketBind:
int32 OS_SocketBindAddress(osal_id_t sock_id, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    OS_common_record_t *         record;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Addr);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID)
        {
            /* Not a socket */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & (OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND | OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED)) != 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be neither bound nor connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl(&token, Addr);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                OS_CreateSocketName(&token, Addr, NULL);
                record->name_entry = stream->stream_name;
                stream->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_SocketListen(osal_id_t sock_id)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        /* This call is only applicable to stream sockets */
        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID || stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_STREAM)
        {
            /* Not a stream socket */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND) == 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be bound to an address already */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & (OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING | OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED)) != 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be neither listening nor connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketListen_Impl(&token);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                stream->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE (-36)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in the provided code are invariant constants. Each if condition depends on runtime values or variables that are assigned from function calls or object fields:

- In OS_SocketBind: the conditions "if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)" and "if (return_code == OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE)" depend on the variable return_code which is set by calls to OS_SocketBindAddress and OS_SocketListen, so these are not invariant constant expressions.

- In OS_SocketBindAddress: conditions such as "if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)", "if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID)", and the bitmask checks on stream->stream_state all depend on runtime values (return_code or fields of stream/record) and therefore are not invariant.

- In OS_SocketListen: the initial "if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)" depends on the function return; subsequent checks (socket_domain, socket_type, and bitmask checks on stream_state) are based on runtime object fields and are not constant expressions.

- There are no loops (while/for/do-while) with constant controlling expressions in the shown code. The only macro-like construct that might perform control (OS_CHECK_POINTER(Addr)) is a parameter check that necessarily depends on the Addr parameter at runtime (not an invariant constant).

Given the above, none of the control expressions appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 (controlling expressions shall not be invariant).
